creditline: Gift of Ruth and Bruce Dayton
department: Chinese, South and Southeast Asian Art
description: misty landscape with rolling hills; building at center; bridge in LLQ; 2 figures at lower center; inscriptions on silk panels
inscription: 4 blocks of text, in black, to R and L of edges of image; 7 stamps, in red, at bottom of text blocks
text:
A colophon on the mounting of this painting written by the collector Wang Wenzhi (1730-1802) attributes this inkwash landscape to the important late Song - early Yuan artist, Gao Kegong. Although associated with Gao's early style, technically and conceptually this moist atmospheric landscape is a clear link to an earlier tradition begun by Mi Fu (1051-1107) during the Northern Song era.
Graduated inkwashes have been applied in a limited range of tonal densities, and only a few brushstrokes, many consisting of simple horizontal dots, are used to construct the impressionistic landscape forms. This basic style, reliant on inkwash technique rather than precise delineation, had tremendous influence on subsequent landscape painting in both China and Japan. This early scroll provides a rare glimpse into the evolution of late 13th to 14th century painting, a critical period when the fundamentals of literati painting began to be formulated.
title: Landscape in the Style of Mi Fu
